Dr. Jemison‚Äôs accomplishments are an inspiration to young people of all races who see that the sky is not the limit. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Et9KhX1XIAALHZ4.jpg

Fascinated by science and space from a young age, she had been further inspired by watching Nichelle Nichols' portrayal of Lieutenant Uhura on Star Trek. She opened communications on the Space Shuttle with Uhura's phrase, "hailing frequencies open." http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Et9KRKRXUAMlYZz.jpg

Dr. Jemison is not only an accomplished scientist, she also worked as a Peace Corps and refugee doctor in Cambodia, Liberia and Sierra Leone. On top of this, she is a dancer and studied with The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

As we celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth, we should remember that our purpose is not to look backwards, but forwards and upwards. The greats of our past were working to create a better future. The accomplishments of Black Americans in science inspire generations of students today. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Et9JlOBXEAgsiJ9.jpg

When she blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Florida in 1992, Dr. Mae Carol Jemison became the first black woman to travel in space. Even as she made history, she was already an accomplished biomedical engineer. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Et9Jc7qXcAk36Uk.jpg
